statement.p: Graph sine and cosine on the same axes, from x=-2\pi to x=2\pi. Mark the points where \sin x has a horizontal tangent. What do these points correspond to, on the graph of cosine?

hint.p: A horizontal tangent line is where the graph appears to level off.

answer.p: The graph f(x)=\sin x has horizontal tangent lines precisely at those points where \cos x=0.

solution.p: The graph f(x)=\sin x has horizontal tangent lines precisely at those points where \cos x=0. This must be true, since \diff{}{x}\{\sin x\}=\cos x: where the derivative of sine is zero, cosine itself is zero.

statement.p: Graph sine and cosine on the same axes, from x=-2\pi to x=2\pi. Mark the points where \sin x has a tangent line of maximum (positive) slope. What do these points correspond to, on the graph of cosine?

hint.p: You are going to mark there points on the sine graph where the graph is the steepest, going up.

answer.p: The graph f(x)=\sin x has maximum slope at those points where \cos x has a maximum. That is, where \cos x = 1.

solution.p: The graph f(x)=\sin x has maximum slope at those points where \cos x has a maximum. This makes sense, because f'(x)=\cos x: the maximum values of the slope of sine correspond to the maximum values of cosine.

statement.p: Differentiate f(x)=\sin x + \cos x +\tan x.

hint.p: You need to memorize the derivatives of sine, cosine, and tangent.

solution.p: You should memorize the derivatives of sine, cosine, and tangent. f'(x)=\cos x - \sin x + \sec^2 x

statement.p: For which values of x does the function f(x)=\sin x + \cos x have a horizontal tangent?

hint.p: There are infinitely many values. You need to describe them all.

answer.p: x=\frac{\pi}{4}+\pi n, for any integer n.

solution.p: f'(x)=\cos x - \sin x, so f'(x)=0 precisely when \sin x = \cos x. This happens at \pi/4, but it also happens at 5\pi/4. By looking at the unit circle, it is clear that \sin x = \cos x whenever x = \frac{\pi}{4}+\pi n for some integer n.

statement.p: Differentiate f(x)=2\sin x \cos x.

solution.p: It is true that 2\sin x \cos x = \sin (2x), but we don't know the derivative of \sin(2x). So, we use the product rule: f'(x)=2\cos x \cos x+2\sin x (-\sin x)=2(\cos^2 x - \sin ^2 x).

statement.p: Differentiate f(x)=e^x\cot x.
Differentiate f(x) = \dfrac{2\sin x + 3 \tan x}{\cos x + \tan x}

p.m: f'(x)=\dfrac{2+3 \sec x + 2 \sin x -2\tan x \sec x+3\sin x \tan x }{(\cos x + \tan x)^2}

statement.p: Differentiate f(x) = \dfrac{5\sec x+1}{e^x}.
Differentiate f(x)=(e^x+\cot x)(5x^6-\csc x).

solution.p:
We use the product rule:
f'(x)&=(e^x+\cot x)(30x^5+\csc x \cot x)+(e^x-\csc^2x)(5x^6-\csc x)

statement.p: Differentiate f(\theta)=\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta \right).

solution.p: We don't know how to differentiate this function as it is written, but an identity helps us. Since \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta \right)=\cos \theta, we see f'(\theta)=\diff{}{\theta}\{\cos \theta\}=-\sin(\theta).

statement.p: Differentiate f(x)=\sin(-x)+\cos(-x).

hint.p: How can you move the negative signs to a location that you can more easily deal with?

solution.p:
We know the derivative of \sin x, but not of \sin(-x). So we re-write f(x) using identities:
f(x)&=\sin(-x)+\cos(-x)
&=-\sin x + \cos x
f'(x)&=-\cos x - \sin x

statement.p: Differentiate s(\theta)=\dfrac{\cos \theta + \sin \theta}{\cos \theta - \sin\theta}.
is differentiable everywhere.

hint.p: The only spot to worry about is when x=0. For f(x) to be differentiable, it must be continuous, so first find the value of b that makes f continuous at x=0. Then, find the value of a that makes the derivatives from the left and right of x=0 equal to each other.

solution.p:
In order for f to be differentiable at x=0, it must also be continuous at x=0. This forces
\amp\lim_{x\to 0^-}f(x) = \lim_{x\to 0^+}f(x) =f(0) \text{or}\qquad \amp\lim_{x\to 0^-}\cos(x) = \lim_{x\to 0^+}(ax+b) =1
or b=1.

statement.p: Find the equation of the line tangent to the graph of y=\cos(x)+2x at x=\dfrac{\pi}{2}.

solution.p:
We compute the derivative of \cos(x)+2x as being -\sin(x)+2, which evaluated at x=\frac{\pi}{2} yields -1+2=1. Since we also compute \cos(\pi/2)+2(\pi/2)=0+\pi, then the equation of the tangent line is
y - \pi = 1\cdot (x-\pi/2).

statement.p: Evaluate \displaystyle \lim_{x\to \pi/3}\left( \dfrac{\cos(x)-1/2}{x-\pi/3}\right). Use any method.

hint.p: This looks like a derivative that you know how to compute.

solution.p: This limit represents the derivative computed at x=\pi/3 of the function f(x)=\cos x. Since the derivative of f(x) is -\sin x, then its value at x=\pi/3 is exactly -\sqrt{3}/2.

statement.p: Show how you can use the quotient rule to find the derivative of tangent, if you already know the derivatives of sine and cosine.

The derivative of the function
f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll} ax+b& \mbox{for }x \lt 0\\ \frac{6\cos x}{2+\sin x+\cos x}& \mbox{for }x\ge 0 \end{array}\right.
exists for all x. Determine the values of the constants a and b.

hint.p: In order for a derivative to exist, the function must be continuous, and the derivative from the left must equal the derivative from the right.

solution.p: In order for the derivative f'(x) to exist at x=0, the limit \ds\lim_{h \rightarrow 0} \dfrac{f(h)-f(0)}{h} must exist. In particular, the limits \ds\lim_{h \rightarrow 0^-} \dfrac{f(h)-f(0)}{h} and \ds\lim_{h \rightarrow 0^+} \dfrac{f(h)-f(0)}{h} must exist and be equal to each other.

When h \to 0^-, this means h \lt 0, so f(h)=ah+b=ah+2. So:
\ds\lim_{h\to 0^-}\dfrac{f(h)-f(0)}{h}=\ds\lim_{h\to 0^-}\dfrac{(ah+2)-2}{h}=\left.\ds\diff{}{x}\left\{ax+2\right\}\right|_{x=0}=a.

statement.p: For which values of x does the derivative of f(x) = \tan x exist?

hint.p: There are infinitely many places where it does not exist.

answer.p: All values of x except x=\frac{\pi}{2}+n\pi, for any integer n.

solution.p: In order for f'(x) to exist, f(x) has to exist. We already know that \tan x does not exist whenever x=\frac{\pi}{2}+n\pi for any integer n. If we look a little deeper, since \tan x = \frac{\sin x}{\cos x}, the points where tangent does not exist correspond exactly to the points where cosine is zero.

From its graph, tangent looks like a smooth curve over its domain, so we might guess that everywhere tangent is defined, its derivative is defined. We can check this: f'(x) = \sec^2 x = \left(\frac{1}{\cos x}\right)^2. Indeed, wherever \cos x is nonzero, f' exists.
So, f'(x) exists for all values of x except when x=\frac{\pi}{2}+n\pi for some integer n.

statement.p: For what values of x does the derivative of \dfrac{10\sin(x)}{x^2+x-6} exist? Explain your answer.

answer.p:
The function is differentiable whenever x^2+x-6\ne 0 since the derivative equals
\frac{10\cos(x)\cdot (x^2+x-6)-10\sin(x)\cdot (2x+1)}{(x^2+x-6)^2},
which is well-defined unless x^2+x-6=0. We solve x^2+x-6=(x-2)(x+3)=0, and get x=2 and x=-3. So, the function is differentiable for all real values x except for x=2 and for x=-3.

solution.p:
The function is differentiable whenever x^2+x-6\ne 0 since the derivative equals
\frac{10\cos(x)\cdot (x^2+x-6)-10\sin(x)\cdot (2x+1)}{(x^2+x-6)^2},
which is well-defined unless x^2+x-6=0. We solve x^2+x-6=(x-2)(x+3)=0, and get x=2 and x=-3. So, the function is differentiable for all real values x except for x=2 and for x=-3.

statement.p: For what values of x does the derivative of \dfrac{x^2+6x+5}{\sin(x)} exist? Explain your answer.

answer.p:
The function is differentiable whenever \sin(x)\ne 0 since the derivative equals
\frac{\sin(x)\cdot (2x+6) - \cos(x)\cdot (x^2+6x+5)}{(\sin x)^2},
which is well-defined unless \sin x = 0. This happens when x is an integer multiple of \pi. So, the function is differentiable for all real values x except x=n\pi, where n is any integer.

solution.p:
The function is differentiable whenever \sin(x)\ne 0 since the derivative equals
\frac{\sin(x)\cdot (2x+6) - \cos(x)\cdot (x^2+6x+5)}{(\sin x)^2},
which is well-defined unless \sin x = 0. This happens when x is an integer multiple of \pi. So, the function is differentiable for all real values x except x=n\pi, where n is any integer.

statement.p: Find the equation of the line tangent to the graph of y=\tan(x) at x=\dfrac{\pi}{4}.

solution.p:
We compute the derivative of \tan(x) as being \sec^2(x), which evaluated at x=\frac{\pi}{4} yields 2. Since we also compute \tan(\pi/4)=1, then the equation of the tangent line is
y - 1 = 2\cdot (x-\pi/4).

statement.p: Find the equation of the line tangent to the graph of y=\sin(x)+\cos(x)+e^x at x=0.

solution.p:
We compute the derivative y' = \cos(x)-\sin(x)+e^x, which evaluated at x=0 yields 1-0+1 = 2. Since we also compute y(0)=0+1+1=2, the equation of the tangent line is
y - 2 = 2(x-0)
ie y=2x+2.

statement.p: For which values of x does the function f(x)=e^x\sin x have a horizontal tangent line?

solution.p: We are asked to solve f'(x)=0. That is, e^x[\sin x + \cos x]=0. Since e^x is always positive, that means we need to find all points where \sin x + \cos x =0. That is, we need to find all values of x where \sin x = - \cos x. Looking at the unit circle, we see this happens whenever x = \frac{3\pi}{4}+n\pi for any integer n.

statement.p:
Let
f(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{ccc} \frac{\sin x}{x}&,&x \neq 0\\ 1&,&x=0 \end{array}\right.
Find f'(0), or show that it does not exist.

hint.p: You can set up the derivative using the limit definition: f'(0)=\ds\lim_{h \to 0}\dfrac{f(h)-f(0)}{h}. If the limit exists, it gives you f'(0); if the limit does not exist, you conclude f'(0) does not exist.

To evaluate the limit, recall that when we differentiated sine, we learned that for h near 0,
\cos h \leq \frac{\sin h}{h}\leq 1

solution.p:
First, we note that our function is continuous, because
\lim_{x \to 0} f(x)=\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin x}{x}=1=f(0)
This is a handy thing to check: if the function were discontinuous at x=0, then we would automatically know that it was not differentiable there.

statement.p: Differentiate the function h(x) = \sin(|x|) and give the domain where the derivative exists.

hint.p: Recall |x|=\left\{\begin{array}{rl} x&x\ge 0\\ -x&x \lt 0 \end{array}\right.. To determine whether h(x) is differentiable at x=0, use the definition of the derivative.

answer.p: h'(x)=\left\{\begin{array}{rl} \cos x&x \gt 0\\ -\cos x&x \lt 0 \end{array}\right. It exists for all x \neq 0.

solution.p:
As usual, when dealing with the absolute value function, we can make things a little clearer by splitting it up into two pieces.
|x|&=\left\{\begin{array}{rl} x&x\ge 0
-x&x \lt 0 \end{array}\right. So, \sin|x|&=\left\{\begin{array}{rl} \sin x&x\ge 0
\sin(-x)&x \lt 0 \end{array}\right. =\left\{\begin{array}{rl} \sin x&x\ge 0
-\sin x&x \lt 0 \end{array}\right.
where we used the identity \sin(-x)=-\sin x. From here, it's easy to see h'(x) when x is anything other than zero. \diff{}{x}\{\sin|x|\}&=\left\{\begin{array}{rl} \cos x&x \gt 0
??&x=0
-\cos x&x \lt 0 \end{array}\right.
To decide whether h(x) is differentiable at x=0, we use the definition of the derivative. One word of explanation: usually in the definition of the derivative, h is the tiny change in x that is going to zero. Since h is the name of our function, we need another letter to stand for the tiny change in x, the size of which is tending to zero. We chose t. \lim_{t \to 0} \frac{h(t+0)-h(0)}{t}&=\lim_{t \to 0}\frac{\sin|t|}{t}
We consider the behaviour of this function to the left and right of t=0: \frac{\sin |t|}{t}&=\left\{\begin{array}{ll} \frac{\sin t}{t} & t\ge 0
\frac{\sin (-t)}{t} & t \lt 0 \end{array}\right. =\left\{\begin{array}{ll} \frac{\sin t}{t} & t\ge 0
-\frac{\sin t}{t} & t \lt 0 \end{array}\right.
Since we're evaluating the limit as t goes to zero, we need the fact that \ds\lim_{t \to 0} \dfrac{\sin t}{t}=1. We saw this in Section, but also we know enough now to evaluate it another way. Using the definition of the derivative:
\lim_{t \to 0}\frac{\sin t}{t}&=\lim_{t \to 0}\frac{\sin (t+0)-\sin (0)}{t}=\left.\diff{}{x}\{\sin x\}\right|_{t=0}=\cos 0=1
At any rate, since we know \ds\lim_{t \to 0} \dfrac{\sin t}{t}=1, then:
\lim_{t \to 0^+} \frac{h(t+0)-h(0)}{t}&=\lim_{t \to 0^+}\frac{\sin t}{t}=1
\lim_{t \to 0^-} \frac{h(t+0)-h(0)}{t}\amp=\lim_{t \to 0^-}\frac{-\sin t}{t}=-1
So, since the one-sided limits disagree, \lim_{t \to 0} \frac{h(t+0)-h(0)}{t}&=DNE
so h(x) is not differentiable at x=0. Therefore, h'(x)&=\left\{\begin{array}{rl} \cos x&x \gt 0
-\cos x&x \lt 0 \end{array}\right.

statement.p:
For the function
f(x) =\left\{\begin{array}{ll} 0 & x\le 0\\ \frac{\sin(x)}{\sqrt{x}} & x \gt 0\end{array}\right.

which of the following statements is correct?
f is undefined at x = 0.
f is neither continuous nor differentiable at x = 0.
f is continuous but not differentiable at x = 0.
f is differentiable but not continuous at x = 0.
f is both continuous and differentiable at x = 0.

hint.p: To decide whether the function is differentiable, use the definition of the derivative.

solution.p: Statement is false, since f(0)=0. Statement cannot hold, since a function that is differentiable is also continuous.

statement.p: Evaluate \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 0} \dfrac{\sin x^{27}+2x^5 e^{x^{99}}}{\sin^5 x}.

hint.p: In this chapter, we learned \ds\lim_{x \to 0}\dfrac{\sin x}{x}=1. If you divide the numerator and denominator by x^5, you can make use of this knowledge.
